titleproper.value: Guide to the Walter Crane Drawings and Papers <num>TAM 308</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Peter Meyer Filardo

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-05-14T19:42:11</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

extent.value: in 1 manuscript box and 1 oversize flat box.

abstract.value: Walter Crane was a British artist, illustrator, author, socialist, and leading practitioner of the Arts and Crafts movement.  This collections consists of letters, postcards, illustrations, a scrapbook, and a manuscript entitled "The Architecture of Art."

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Donated by Albert Boni, April 8, 1971, who purchased these items in December 1970 from H. M. Fletcher Rare Books (London). The accession number related to this gift is 1971.009.

Walter Crane (1845-1915) was a British artist, illustrator, author, socialist, and leading practitioner of the Arts and Crafts movement.  His illustrations and political cartoons appeared widely in labor and socialist circles, including newspapers, literature, and printed ephemera.  Crane also provided illustrations for fine editions of classic and contemporary literature.  He also wrote on topics of art theory, including <emph render="italic">The Claims of Decorative Art</emph> (1892), in which he argued that art could not flourish in a society with an unfairly distribution of wealth.

The Walter Crane Drawings and Papers contains letters, postcards, illustrations, a scrapbook, and a manuscript concerning Crane's artistic endeavors and socialist beliefs.  Correspondence includes letters to Annie Besant, John Page Hopps, Harry Quilter, Edmund Russell, and various clients. Other materials include a poem; a memorial article; collection of socialist postcards; advertisements illustrated by Crane; a scrapbook containing several illustrated newspaper clippings; a manuscript entitled <emph render="italic">The Architecture of Art</emph> (1887); and the "Gesso Collection," a set of drawings and illustrations by Crane and others with accompanying notes concerning the use of gesso for preparing painting surfaces.

subject.value: Arts and crafts movement |z Great Britain.
